content.description: Researchers in the Gal√°pagos Islands measured the average beak size in a population of finches from 1976 to 1984, as shown in the graph below. Birds with smaller beaks are better suited for grasses and soft seeds, while birds with larger beaks are better suited for seeds and nuts. In years with less rainfall, there are fewer grasses to feed on and the finches rely more on seeds for food. In 1977, 1980, and 1982, there were droughts, and the area experienced significantly less rainfall than average.
content.question: Which statement is best supported by the data in the graph?

choices.label: Finches were better able to find mates, and the population size increased in 1977 because of the abundance of grasses.
Finches with larger beaks were more likely to survive in 1980 because they were able to feed primarily on seeds and nuts during the drought.

The average beak size in 1981 increased to <math alttext="9.8 millimeters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>9.8</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"></mspace><mtext>mm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> because finches had access to unlimited resources.
The finch population declined from 1983 to 1984 due to a decrease in habitat.

content.answer: Finches with larger beaks were more likely to survive in 1980 because they were able to feed primarily on seeds and nuts during the drought.

skill.text: Skill 5.B: Describe relationships among variables in data represented.
